Legal_Issue: Was the Minister's decision to deny additional relief from interest and penalties reasonable under s. 220(3.1) of the Income Tax Act?
Application_Facts: Applicant cited health issues, third-party delays, and financial hardship but failed to provide sufficient evidence.
Decision_Outcome: Minister denied taxpayer relief; court upheld the decision.
Remedy_Requested: Waiver or cancellation of interest and penalties
Defendant_Behavior: CRA's denial based on perceived negligence in fulfilling tax obligations
Grounds_for_Claim: Extraordinary circumstances, CRA actions, financial hardship
Assessment_Factor: Health issues, third-party delays, financial hardship, sufficiency of evidence, taxpayer negligence
Applicable_Legislation: s. 220(3.1) of the Income Tax Act
Evidence_Used: Applicant's submissions regarding health, delays, and financial hardship
Application_Basis: Request for relief from interest and penalties due to alleged extraordinary circumstances
Relief_Sought: Additional relief from interest and penalties
Governing_Rule: Minister has discretionary authority to waive or cancel penalties/interest if justified by extraordinary circumstances, CRA actions, or financial hardship
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence to support claims of hardship or extraordinary circumstances
Cause_Description: Denial of taxpayer relief request due to insufficient evidence and perceived negligence
Evidence_Handling: Minister considered arguments but found evidence inadequate
Evidence_Issues: Failure to substantiate claims with adequate documentation
Decision_Rationale: Decision aligned with guidelines and considered all relevant factors; negligence found in tax compliance
